utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
(Chinese spoken)
He tells me we don't even know where to rebuild.
He's heard that county lines may be redrawn and that neighboring Beichuan County, one of the hardest-hit areas, could be moved here.
We might even lose our land, he says.
It's easy to see how that could happen.
Just across the road, a tent city has sprung up - some 1,500 people from Beichuan County, all homeless since the earthquake.
Brick walkways have been laid between rows of government-issued blue tents.
Sinks and showers have been brought in; a communal outhouse has been built.
And on the edge of the tent city, a local family has set up a simple outdoor kitchen.
Ms. GO MIEN(ph) (Resident): (Chinese spoken)
Mr.
GO LUNGBEEN(ph) (Resident, Husband of Go Mien): (Chinese spoken)
Go Mien and her husband, Lungbeen, say they get an endless stream of people coming to boil water and cook.
(Chinese spoken)
We're all victims of the earthquake, Go says.
Right now, we're just dealing with the here and now.
Who knows what will happen down the road?
Shortly after the quake, government officials came to Yongan to take over land for the tent city.
Jo Tung Xio(ph) is one of the farmers who's had to make way for the tents.
In return, she received compensation - a lot, she says.
(Chinese spoken)
I find her in front of what was her home.
Now it's just a pile of rubble.
She's tending to her flock of ducks.
She says she's worried about finding food for the ducks, and she's worried about her family's future.
(Chinese spoken)
All of our money went into this house, she says.
We had a refrigerator, a hot water heater, a TV, nice furnishings upstairs and down.
Everything was smashed to pieces.
(Chinese spoken)
All these outsiders coming in will have a big impact on our lives, she tells me.
They're already going through our ruined homes looking for wood to burn.
But how can we say no to them?
(Chinese spoken)
Just before dinnertime, a shipment of new iron woks, three feet in diameter, arrive in the tent city.
Evacuees get to work building brick stoves.
Meanwhile across the dirt path, farmers bundle together husks from the recent canola harvest, fuel for the new stoves.
This bustle of activity is something Yongan has never quite experienced before, and the quiet life that existed before May 12 is something these farmers wonder if they'll ever see again.
Andrea Hsu, NPR News, in Chengdu, China.
From NPR News, this is All Things Considered.
I'm Michele Norris.
A lot has changed for Senator Hillary Clinton in the last year and a half.
She's gone from being the solid frontrunner to the likely runner-up.
She says she's staying in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination.
But even with a big win in Kentucky, she can't seem to narrow Barack Obama's lead in delegates.
NPR's national political correspondent Mara Liasson has this report on what went wrong with the Clinton campaign.
When Hillary Clinton launched her campaign, the announcement said she was in it to win it.
And for a while, it looked like she would.
She had money, endorsements, a huge lead in the polls - everything she needed to convince most of the political world that her nomination was all but inevitable.
Her campaign set out to prove she could be a tough, credible commander-in-chief, a high bar for a female candidate, and she cleared it - dominating the field in debate after debate.
She made Barack Obama look weak and inexperienced in South Carolina when he answered a question about a hypothetical 9/11-style attack by saying he would first check with the first responders.
Clinton's answer communicated strength and experience.
I think a president must move as swiftly as is prudent to retaliate.
But, says Mark Mellman, a Democratic strategist who's neutral this year, even from the beginning, Clinton made a fundamental strategic mistake.
She clearly went with the wrong message at the beginning.
She ran under the banner of experience.
We've known for two years that Democratic primary voters would rather have a candidate of change than a candidate of experience by two to one.
For a year, she chose to be on the short end of that stick.
She didn't have to do that, she did, it was a serious mistake.
